mainheading.heading: Introducing Paccal VetÂ® - CA1:Chemotherapy designed with dogs in mind.

title.title: Paccal Vet-CA1 is indicated for the treatment of:

textpanel.sectioncopy:
Contraindications, warnings and precautions: Do not use in dogs that have clinically relevant low neutrophil counts or that have concurrent infections. Do not use in dogs that are pregnant, lactating or intended for breeding. Extravasation during administration can cause focal tissue necrosis and should be avoided. Paclitaxel is cytotoxic, and can cause birth defects and fertility disorders in humans. Pregnant and breast feeding women should not prepare or administer the product. In the hospital, standard measures for the handling of cytotoxic drugs should be used and hospital staff and clients should avoid contact with the drug and the excretions of the patient being treated for the recommended time period. The client should be educated in safe handling of the excretions from the dog being treated. More detailed preparation and administration information as well as special instructions for avoiding human exposure to waste products are supplied in the package insert and the client information sheet.

Side effects and adverse reactions: Paclitaxel can cause severe, transient bone marrow suppression within four to seven days of administration. It can also cause adverse gastrointestinal reactions due to transient gastrointestinal mucosal cell toxicity. Premedication with antiemetics is recommended. Paclitaxel has a narrow safety margin and can cause multiple adverse reactions. In field studies all the dogs treated (n=168) experienced at least one adverse reaction. Generally, adverse reactions were manageable with appropriate patient monitoring and supportive care. The most frequent adverse reactions were: neutropenia (82%); vomiting (79%); anorexia (76%); diarrhea (70%), and lethargy (69%). Less frequent but still significant adverse reactions included: alopecia (39%), dehydration (26%); dermatitis (24%); hepatopathy (19%); pyrexia (13%); edema (14%); lameness (10%). Other, less frequent but serious (more than 2% and less than 10%) adverse reactions included: urine abnormality, pruritus, erythema, anemia, loss of body condition, ulceration, thrombocytopenia, neoplasia, polydipsia, conjunctivitis, and death (including euthanasia).

See package insert for full prescribing information.
